results.description:
If you, like me, are "staycationing" this Memorial Day weekend, then let's do some sailing Monday. In an unusual twist of events, I actually have the day off.

Sabina, my Islander 28, is electric, quiet and clean. She also has a fully functioning "head" (toilet for you land folks). Itinerary depends on the wind so I can't make any promises, but those of you have have sailed with me before know I'm pretty flexible and generally chill. Bring lunch snacks, wine, beer or whatever else you desire. I always have potable water on board, but bring your own canteen!

Experience desired but not necessary. See you Monday!

results.description:
Hello, everyone. The Word Party has moved to MONDAYS, as of March 23! RSVPs are greatly appreciated but not necessary. While we like to start on time, it's not a big deal if you arrive late. We'll whisper what we're working on and help you get going..

Feel free to SHARE THIS EMAIL with anyone who might enjoy our little writing adventures. Happy to answer any questions you may have, via email or phone.

Warm Wishes,

Ira Marlowe (host)

THE WORD PARTY is a weekly drop-in class focusing on improvisational writing and other writing-related games and exercises.

Partly based on the work of Julia Cameron ("The Artist's Way") and Natalie Goldberg ("Writing Down the Bones"), our goal is to help stimulate creativity and help generate new ideas. We offer a friendly, humorous environment for anyone who enjoys writing and we're open to writers of all levels.

Each session features a variety of writing games and assignments lasting between five and twenty minutes. By writing non-stop, without lifting pen from paper (or fingers from keys), the internal critic is silenced and the unconscious mind gets a welcome chance to play. (You may be amazed at what you come up with!)

Afterward, participants have the option of sharing what they've written. However, you are never under any pressure to do so.

I believe you will find this an enjoyable resource for fiction writers, journal-keepers, poets, dramatists, comedians, and songwriters. Get past blocks, find new inspiration, meet kindred spirits, have a great time!

WHEN: Monday evenings, 7:00 to 9 PM.

WHERE: The Monkey House Theater, 1638 University Ave, three blocks from North Berkeley BART. Street parking is generally very easy.

HOW MANY: 6-12 participants.

COST: Sliding scale donation, $15-25

Word Party host Ira Marlowe is a songwriter, playwright and storyteller, currently serving as composer/lyricist for the SF Mime Troupe, the Tony Award-winning political theater company. He recently wrote and produced Tales From Varley Mansion, a Halloween "mini musical", directed by Andrew Nance. He's won the international "Songs Inspired by Literature" contest and the SF Weekly "Best of the Bay" song competition, plus the coveted Parents' Choice Award for his series of BrainyTunes kids' CDs. He's amazed how often the short short stories he writes in this class have found their way into songs.
results.how_to_find_us: Just three blocks from North Berkeley BART.  Street parking is usually easy.
results.name: Meet in Berkeley for spontaneous improvisational writing adventures!

results.description:
This meetup is for Rhino enthusiasts of all stripes! I am interested in creating an in-person Rhino local community for those who are interested in the platform and it's class of output. There is no charge for attendance, but if you need more help than the meet up can provide there are individual and group lessons or consultation available.

The reward for attendees is to learn about other people's experiences in new media, local scenes and firms, and to see what the Bay Area is offering the world of innovative design, modeling and throughput.

Just show up with your latest problems, conundrums or techniques in Rhino, Flamingo or any other related plug-in, and we will have a chance to swap experiences and inspirations.

Experienced students, fabricators and all professionals are welcome. I am a designer using Rhino on a daily basis for the design and fabrication of public art and architectural details, including output to render, 3D printing (Z-corp, Objet), industrial laser, water jet, and various other job shop formats. Ultimately, I'd like to get a group together who can swap contacts so we can have an additional source of problem solving ideas, especially when we have a tough problem crop up right before deadline and when the regular Rhino online help forum is just not doing the trick.

So please, whether new to Rhino or an old hand, let me and other potential attendees know your of interest: sign up and stop by! While reservations are not required and attendance is open, if no one has indicated that they will be attending then there will be a chance that I will not be there; however if there is even one member who RSVP's I'll be sure to be there.

Hope to see you there!

- - David

results.description:
The Real Vegan Cheese project is an award-winning collaboration between Counter Culture Labs and our sister lab BioCurious in Sunnyvale, to make real cheese without using any animals!

Real Vegan Cheese is a not a cheese substitute! It all starts with regular old baker's yeast. Through synthetic biology, we engineer our yeast to become milk-protein factories. Our milk proteins are then combined with water and vegan oil to make Vegan Milk which is ultimately converted into Real Vegan Cheese through standard cheese-making processes - just like cheese made from cow or goat milk!

Feel free to come check us out. We're hoping to actually get work done in these meetings, so we will likely not give an extensive introduction to any newbies, but you're more than welcome to sit in and absorb some biohacking-in-action.


For now, we will be meeting every first Monday of the month at BioCurious, and the other Mondays in Oakland.

Join from a PC, Mac, iPad, iPhone or Android device:

Please click this URL to start or join. https://zoom.us/j/820128495 Or, go to https://zoom.us/join and enter meeting ID:[masked]

Join from dial-in phone line:

Dial: +1 (415)[masked] or +1 (646)[masked] Meeting ID:[masked]

results.description:
We generally think about cells as small, stupid building blocks, with the idea that to build anything complicated, or do any sort of complex behavior, one needs large numbers of cells. But in fact cells can have highly complex forms, both internal and external, and are capable of an amazing array of behaviors. It is not obvious how cells are able to develop complex internal anatomies, and indeed very little is known about the origins of cell geometry. Where does shape arise from collections of molecules? Perhaps even more fascinating than the complex shapes of cells is the fact that individual cells can often show a wide range of apparently purposeful behaviors. If you watch a cell going about its business it is hard not to start thinking of it as an animal or a robot. These behaviors require decision making and computation, and again it is not at all clear how these computational activities arise from the collection of molecules in the cell.

Understanding how cells generate form and carry out behaviors is likely to be valuable in practice. Metabolic engineering is currently focused entirely on altering enzyme expression levels, but unless the size and shape of the cell's internal reaction vessels (organelles) can be reprogrammed, the potential impact of changing enzyme levels is likely to be limited by the capacity of those vessels. In medicine, many diseases show alterations of cell shape but we have literally no understanding of why this happens. Learning how cells regenerate could suggest new ways to induce regeneration in damaged human cells, providing an alternative to stem cell replacement therapy. Finally, if it is really true that cells are computing devices, perhaps we can learn how to reprogram a cell's behavior, either to turn cells into micron-scale robots (for example by making white blood cells that can attack cancer targets) or to alter the behavior of cells throughout the body.

The giant single celled ciliate Stentor coeruleus has a size and structural complexity that rivals that of the animal embryo. Stentor can perform all of the key processes of development biology, including axiation, pattern formation, and induction, all within a single cell. Moreover, when a Stentor cell is cut into pieces, the pieces can regenerate intact cells with normal geometry. The ability of Stentor cells to heal wounds and regenerate allowed microsurgical experiments on Stentor development, which were carried out between 1890 and the mid 1980's. But Stentor was never developed as a molecular model system and despite the wealth of surgical results, virtually nothing is known about the molecular mechanisms by which Stentor is able to develop and regenerate. We have sequenced the Stentor genome and developed methods to perturb gene function using RNA interference. We are now conducting RNAi based screens to identify genes involved in regeneration. At the same time, the genome now allows us to use RNA sequencing to map the genomic programs that underlie specific regeneration events. Stentor is also notable for its rich behavioral repertoire. Each cell can choose between a range of different motile, contractile, and feeding behaviors, implying the existence of decision making circuitry. It has even been reported that Stentor cells can show simple forms of nonassociative learning, an idea that we are now exploring by combining automated testing systems with RNAi screening.
results.name: Regeneration and Learning in a Single Cell with Wallace Marshall of UCSF

Come out and enjoy a mid-week evening trail run in Tilden Park. Expect anywhere from 5-10 miles with plenty of hills. Anyone and everyone is welcome!

Depending on who shows up, we may split up the group to accommodate different paces and distances. The trails at Tilden are well marked, and there are plenty of options for extending or shortening runs.

It will be assumed that everyone is self-sufficient and prepared to get back to the parking lot alone. (This is a "run your own pace run". If you're fast, don't feel like you need to wait. If you're a bit slower, don't worry about it, but make sure you know how to get back!)

We meet at the trail head right across the creek from the parking lot. Please post if you need a ride and/or want to carpool, or you have any other concerns.

***** Fall and Winter Notice***** This is now a night run. Bring a flashlight or headlamp!

See you on the trail!

results.description:
****RSVP HERE ON EVENTBRITE****

About Telegraph Prep:

Telegraph Prep will teach you basic programming fundamentals using the JavaScript language. If you’re serious about launching your career into Silicon Valley as a highly sought-after engineer, this course is the starting point.

Weeks 3 and 4 will be focused on teaching what you need to know to master functional programming and higher order functions. We've designed a capstone project for you to take on with a pair, and with our technical mentorship, to solidify your understanding of functional programming.


Week 3 Intermediate:
Tuesday: Scopes
Wednesday: Closures
Thursday: Scopes + Closures (review)
Friday: Callbacks/Higher Order Functions
Sunday: Optional Study Day

Week 4 Putting it All Together:
Monday: Capstone Project
Tuesday: Capstone Project
Wednesday: Capstone Project
Thursday: Capstone Project
Sunday: Optional Study Day

If, by Week 4 Day 5, you don’t feel like you have a strong command of the JavaScript language we haven’t done our job.

What’s the commitment?

Our 1-month intensive is meant to be as similar to bootcamp life as possible. You and your classmates will spend at least 24 hours a week studying JavaScript after work and on the weekends. The current times and dates for the class are

Monday through Thursday 6:30pm - 9pm
NOTE: Due to Memorial Day, The first week will be running from Tuesday-Friday at 6:30pm - 9pm

Sundays 10am - 5pm.

We want students who are serious about taking the next step in their professional career and making every session is crucial to getting the most out of the class.

And the cost?

The cost of the 1-month intensive is $250 per 2 weeks and $500 all together, but once you pass our technical interview we’ll credit that toward your tuition for 3-month career accelerator. If, for some reason, you don’t pass our interview and/or don’t have a strong command of the JavaScript language after taking weeks 3 & 4 we’ll refund you 50% of what you paid.

Are there scholarships available?


Yes, there are a limited number of need-based scholarships available. Apply Here.

results.description:
I can tell that Measurement is going to take three meetings. Rather than occupy an entire month with it, we will temporarily accelerate our meeting schedule by interpolating this May 26 date in order to finish Measurement on June 2. (More about why Measurement is worth a longer look here.)


We will dive into the idea of scales, probably in the context of the psychological measurements that dominated discussion on May 19, though obviously scales are used in commerce as well. (Yes, we are availing ourselves of multiple senses of the word scale.) The scale as a physical instrument focuses us the reality of measurement, while its mode of operation--of balancing opposing forces--highlights the duality of measurement. And there's Lady Justice, yielding the judgment of her eyesight to the balancing of a mechanical scale.

Those of you inclined toward what I've termed a "quantitative interest" should not miss this one: that is, if you've ever cited one cause or reason being "greater" than another to make your point, then you ought to develop with us an understanding of what that means in a broad, philosophical sense.

To be further developed during the week, and in Show Your Work. Please lend us a hand (or mind).


Jeff
results.how_to_find_us: usually in front of the dining area
results.name: Balancing Scales (Measurement II)

results.description:
I had an epiphany recently about what I like.

I like men’s gatherings, I like hiking, I like beer, and I like talking about women and sex. I'm know I'm not alone here, so let’s bring these four elements together for the most epic men’s group ever.

Here's why each of these four elements are awesome:

Gathering with other men – The more quality time I spend with other men, the better my life gets. Our culture doesn’t acknowledge this need enough. 90% of the men I know would benefit from more “man time.”

Hiking – After staring at a computer screen all day, don’t you just want to get outside and blow off steam? I happen to live a 5-minute walk away from Tilden Park. It’s the most spectacular backyard ever.

Beer – To be honest, I’m not a big drinker but I like a good beer. If you don’t drink, that’s cool. Bring a root beer.

Sex – Sex is a topic that men tend to talk about with a lot of bravado and not a lot of substance. I’m going to guide us into a more vulnerable conversation so we can truly support and inspire each other.

The plan:
- Meet at my house at 7:30. We’ll meditate for 10 minutes, and I’ll set the stage for the conversations we’ll have on our hike.
- We’ll leave my house by 7:45 with beers in hand and head into Tilden to enjoy nature and talk about man stuff.
- We’ll be back by 9:15 at the very latest to wrap up, say goodbye, and share our final thoughts.

What to bring:
- Hiking shoes and layers
- A bottle of craft beer
- Willingness to be vulnerable

See you soon!

Peter
Men's Relationship Coach
www.unconventionalrelationship.com
results.name: Let's Hike, Drink Beer, and Talk About Women and Sex

We will meet on Euclid in front of the Rose Garden and take steep long stairways and pathways in Berkeley Hills. We will have yoga practice at the park, returning back to the Rose Garden.

For those of you who have never been on Berkeley Hills stairways, this is not an easy urban walk. Even experienced hikers struggle on those steps. Please, consider this when you sign up.

results.description:
One of the most important decisions you make as a solo entrepreneur is which legal structure to choose for your business.

The choice you make will impact your everyday life and work in terms of liability, taxation and reporting.

Join us for a presentation by attorney Jesse Woo and get a tour of your options, including:

• Sole proprietor, where you keep 100% ownership and liability.

• General Partnership, where you split ownership and liability.

• S Corp which has similarities to a partnership where income and losses are passed on through shareholders

• C Corp, which exists separately from its owners

• LLC, where members are not personally responsible for the company's finances

Jesse will present an overview of possibilities, and then take your questions.

Our agenda:

6:30-7:00 PM Networking

7:00-7:15 PM Icebreaker

7:15-7:40 PM "Choosing the Right Legal Structure for Your Business" with attorney Jesse Woo

7:40-8:00 PM Brain Exchange

8:00-8:30 PM Networking
results.name: Choosing the Right Legal Structure for Your Solo Business

While accompanying someone through the final phase of life can be an amazing and healing experience, it can also be demanding, exhausting and sometime tarnished by resentments and regrets. The challenges of this delicate balance are revealed in this second film of the awarding winning series, Secrets of Life and Death by Dr. Michelle Peticolas.

* What to do to avoid burnout.

This is a great opportunity to see one of my films and to learn some of the essentials of successful caregiving.

results.description:
A Safe and Fun Space... with Voice and Movement... to Create Conscious Community & Authentic Connection

***RSVP Here, and then Get Your Early Bird Ticket at http://connectionjam.eventbrite.com.***

Does sharing LOLs and Facebook statuses leave you feeling a little empty? Tired of superficial conversation... or even people acting authentic (when it doesn't really ring true)?

Or, do you attend dance and movement events, where you dance next to people, but would enjoy both moving and talking?

It's time for a new paradigm for connection. One that's not digital... beyond superficial banter... is not about just relating mentally from our heads... and also has healthy boundaries!

Welcome to... Connection Jams.

WHAT'S A CONNECTION JAM?

Connection Jams are guided processes - that is, it's not just open forums where anything goes. In a safe and fun space, participants are taken through the Spiral Path of Connection - which begins with connecting with yourself... and eventually moves into interconnection. Download a free guide, Redefining Connection, that explains the 9 aspects of connection - and reframes how connection can be easier and more fulfilling.

This safe container takes participants through a fun and embodied process (that is, you'll be moving around a fair amount - as well as having dialogue), that helps connecting with others become easy, fun, safe, and energizing.

WHO'S IT FOR?

People with bodies who breathe, and would like to enjoy being around other people more.

...No, seriously: it's especially appreciated by people who've done personal and/or spiritual growth work. Plus if you enjoy embodied practices, like movement, dance and yoga, you'll dig it. (No, you do not need to be good at them! (No, you do not need to be good at them! You may even be very intellectual - and yet know that your body is a helpful thing to have.)

You may also desire to create community with others who are on a conscious path.

Or, you may be an introvert who feels drained around others... and wish connecting would be easier and energizing.

Note: while it's neither a dating nor a business event in particular, you may well make personal or professional connections...and of course make new friends.

WHAT WILL HAPPEN?

1. MOVEMENT AND EMBODIMENT. The first half of the event focuses on connecting with yourself (so that you really feel like you) and connecting with others through movement, nonverbal communication, and dialogue.

2. ACTING, VOICE and IMPROV EXERCISES that are may be fun, or deep, or just different. These are largely expert tools used to enhance public speaking, self-expression, and "the Performance of Your Life (TM)."

3. DEEPENING DIALOGUE. No standard, unfulfilling banter that everyone dreads. While you by no means will be forced to talk about things you don't want to, unusual and yet fun prompts and topics will help you get to know people as 3D humans, way beyond standard "what do you do" type statements.

And...

• Warning: You may very well have fun.

• You may walk away with new friends or people who adore who you are and what you do.

• Learn new tools for connecting more fully. This might feel a little new or intense at times... just like any new growth area feels. And, it's presented in a fun, engaging way, with zero pressure - where you can always do what feels best for you.

WHAT YOU WON'T FIND...

• Inappropriate touch and bad boundaries... or anything resembling it. (Note: this is not Contact Improvisation... nor is it sexualized contact.)

• Fake, new-agey "authenticity" (which really is just another facade).

• Alcohol. Relax and be yourself without substances.

BRING: A water bottle and a snack if you'll need it. Plus, wear movement/yoga/dance-type clothes you'll relax in.

ABOUT THE FACILITATOR: Since 1996, Jonathan Bender, MS, MFA, has coached and taught workshops to thousands, focusing on self-expression, public speaking, personal growth and "the performance of your life." The founder of WholeSpeak, LLC, he spends his time teaching how to show up in life and on stage with authenticity, power, and dynamic presence. He also trains and certifies coaches in the WholeSpeak Method. Jonathan is a professional theatre director, actor and writer; he holds an MFA in Theater: Contemporary Performance and a Master's in Performance Studies and Speech Communication. Jonathan also runs Conscious Business Bay Area.

Learn more about Connection Jams at http://www.ConnectionJams.com.
results.name: **Connection Jam** - Movement, Connection, and Deep Play

results.description:
Vibologists and Change Agents:

Channel the Vibe of Love & Transformation in yourself. Tune in and Tune up with sound! Sound is a vehicle to tune your inner vibrations.

Connect your voice with yourself, your heart, your thoughts, your gut, your feelings. Be an open vessel of the infinite universal source. Tune into your natural vibrations and rhythms, and escort these tangible undulations within to the place they really want to be by steering them as you listen to them, navigating through worlds within.

We open our voice, and deepen our understanding of our lives as we listen to our inner vibrations. We’ll touch our hearts, sing with and from our souls, and deepen the journey of transformation we are each on right now, together. Your are your vibrations.

Denise Eve using the Light Nucleus by Sid Gabriel

Denise Eve, Vibologist

Bio: Psychonautical and cosmonautical explorer Eve Echo has spent her life spelunking her consciousness for fun. Focusing on vibrations as the potency of sound, music, light, magnetics,thought, somatics, brain and neurobiology, and its influence in the anatomical and heartfelt world of our embedded embodied selves, she believes we have the ability to expand our consciousness, connect with each other, and be change agents toward the shift we seek, thus influencing our health, our relations and communities through our vibes.

The official forms she has studied are DNA 1, 2 and Intuitive Anatomy in Theta Healing; Sound Therapy and Music in Chant, Freeform Jams, Bhajan and Sanyasin bands; Celestial Speaking in Tian Gong; Kundalini Yoga; Qi Gong, Dance and Reiki. Currently she is a masters candidate in Philosophy, Cosmology, and Consciousness program at the California Institute of Integral Studies in San Francisco. She is also developing an online resource and magazine VibeScience.

As an intuitive and explorer Denise Eve offers her vitality to promote our inner vibes that resonate with our core heart, spirit and soul embodied.

~

VibeScience
results.name: Channel the Vibe

results.description:
Ace Monster Toys (AMT) holds Micro-controller board (Raspberry Pi, Arduino, etc.) Nights every other Wednesday. Open to the public, come work on micro controllers, Arduinos, Raspberry Pis, Edisons, whatever you want.
Resident "expert" David R. will be on hand to help you get started, provide parts to build your own cheap arduino clone, give advice on your current project, or give ideas. Typically there's no specific agenda so feel free to come and just hang out and see our awesome space (and consider becoming a member).

AMT's meetup page lists all their upcoming events as "Raspberry Pi & Arduino Nights":

http://www.meetup.com/Ace-Monster-Toys/

... but David and I agreed that with the plethora of new devices we should probably broaden the description to encompass all of the various new micro-controller development platforms available

Tell them Peter from the Raspberry Pi Meetup sent you. Questions? Email [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Look for the blueish warehouse building. Buzz #214 on the entry panel, just to the left of the big garage. Here's the google maps: http://goo.gl/MqJ7b

We are a co-ed soccer group for all experience levels. As long as we get at least 8 RSVPs for a game, then we'll play so make sure to RSVP if you plan on attending.

This park normally keeps the field lights on until 10 PM, but we play until 9:45 PM so we have time to pack up. All pick-up games are subject to the lights being on.

Rain: If it's raining or it has rained a few hours before our meetup time, our pick-up game will be cancelled so we don't unnecessarily damage the grass :(

Please bring a white and dark colored shirt so we can divide up into teams. Turf cleats will help preserve the grass field so bring them if you don't mind wearing them. As always, play at your own risk and always watch out for your mates on and off the pitch.

Your donations help pay for cones, goals, pennies, meetup fees, etc. so please make sure to contribute by donating $5 through paypal or by paying cash in person.

Thanks

Welcome!

Are you a Queer Femme who is looking to build community? On the 2nd and 4th Wednesdays of the month, 7:30pm-9:30pm, there is a confidential social and support group at the Pacific Center in Berkeley.

This group is for anyone who identifies, has ever identified, or is wondering about identifying as a Queer Femme, whatever that means to you. We welcome all bodies and backgrounds, styles, spectrums and presentations, as long as you're 18+.

If you have any questions about the group, please email [masked]. *** Emails sent through MeetUp will not receive a response***

Hope to see y'all there ♥ $5-$20 suggested donation. No one turned away for lack of funds.

About peer-led groups at the Pacific Center: Pacific Center offers ongoing, drop-in, peer-facilitated groups covering a range of topics and issues important to our communities. These groups provide connection, support, information, and enjoyment. Peer groups are volunteer-led and are not therapy groups.

results.description:
Witness 3,000 pounds of glass being poured at 2200 Degrees!

Made possible by SyncFab’s Made in California Factory Tours Initiative – Take an early lunch break with fellow GIANT scale cast glass Enthusiasts at a world-class architectural and specialty glass casting studio in Oakland - the largest (20,000 sq. ft.) and earliest (1969) glass studio of its kind in North America and the Bay Area.

The tour will be co-led by owner and world reclaimed cast glass artist, John Lewis, together with SyncFab artist and materials developer Nick Agid.

We will begin in the Clean Room and work our way to the Sand Blasting Area then onto Cold Working and finally the Hot Shop where we will see 3,000 pounds of hot glass being poured at 2200 Degrees. The pieces will be de-molded and put into annealing ovens to cool slowly depending on the glass thickness for a process that will last for weeks or even months. End up in John Lewis’ Gallery across the street where we will have further discussion.

John Lewis, internationally known and considered to be one of the top cast glass artists in the world, is one of the first artists to set up a hot glass studio in the Bay Area. With major commissions including Hearst Tower, the Oklahoma City Memorial and Morgan Stanley in NYC - his works are in the collections of The Boston Museum of Fine Art and the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

Nick Agid is former professor at Art Center College of Design and Otis, whose work is in the permanent collection of the Los Angeles County Museum of Art (see his work at <a>www.agidarts.com)</a>.


NOTE: Dress for the occasion in dark work clothes with non-slip closed toed shoes. You may get a little dirty because graphite is everywhere, as it used in the molds.
results.name: Giant Architectural Glass Casting Tour: 3000 LBS of Glass poured at 2200 Degrees

results.description: Move your body, chat and get to know Bay Area midwives and other moms! Pregnant folks and postpartum alike are welcome to join in. Bring a water bottle, extra layers, carriers and umbrellas. This location can accommodate strollers and just-walking infants. Heavy rain cancels. Meet at the parking circle at the end of the road at Cesar Chavez Park
results.name: Moms & Midwives Stroll at the Marina

results.description:
It's summer time! Which means that most of the students have returned home or gone on vacation and Berkeley is once again open for adult libations. Beta Lounge IS NOW A FULL BAR! That’s right, in addition to a great beer selection and wine by the glass, you can now get real cocktails at Beta. Beta is a hidden Berkeley treasure and is conveniently located within walking distance of the downtown Berkeley BART station. A funny thing happened when I tried to negotiate a deal with Beta, their happy hour is already very reasonable and lasts until 9 PM. The beer and wine selection rotates so for more information please see their website. I hope to see you there!

Cheers,

Rick
results.how_to_find_us: Although the VIP couches are reserved for us, we tend to stay at the bar.
results.name: Reclaiming Berkeley

Figured I should update this cause we never really made it to that 4.5 mph but we do it in an hour including at least 2 sets of steps. Not too shabby! Anyhow, we're out there trying :)

Let's Meet on the bench near the Harrison and 21st streets crosswalk, right across from the Kaiser building

results.description:
Adventure Run is a free, 60-minute scavenger-like fun run filled with raffle prizes, music and even a beer garden.

Free, but an RSVP is required. Click here

Your Adventure starts when you arrive early to collect your supplies (check-in) and try cool new products from Adventure Run sponsors for free. When the event map is revealed, simply plot your Adventure and hit the road with the goal of collecting as many raffle tickets from as many checkpoints as possible in 60 minutes. Then you’ll run back to your Road Runner Sports store feeling on top of the world for the work you just accomplished and the fun that lies ahead. You’ll high-five new friends, grab a beer and have your chance to win over $3,000 in free raffle prizes.

Schedule:

6:00pm: Arrive early to sign in inside the store

6:30-7:30 pm: Run or Walk to Fun Checkpoints at Your Own Pace

7:30-8 pm: Win Free Raffle Prizes & Enjoy Pyramid Beer Garden
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the store
results.name: Adventure Run Scavenger Hunt & Beer Garden

results.description:
Berkeley Road Runner Sports Adventure Run is a FREE, 60-minute scavenger-like fun run filled with hundreds of friends, giveaways, raffle prizes, music and free beer! Enough said?

Your Adventure starts when you arrive early to collect your supplies (check-in) and try cool new products from Adventure Run sponsors for FREE! You’ll feel mounting excitement as the map of checkpoints is unveiled before hundreds of runners and walkers, just like you!

You’ll plot your adventure then hit the road with the goal of collecting as many raffle tickets from as many checkpoints as possible in 60 minutes. Your Adventure is at your pace so run, walk, sprint, hop…whatever works for you.

Checkpoints range from a few steps to up to 3-miles from your Road Runner Sports store with crazy obstacles and opportunities to earn more raffle tickets along the way!

You’ll run back to your Road Runner Sports store feeling on top of the world for the work you just accomplished and the fun that lies ahead! You’ll high-five new friends, grab a beer or other tasty beverage, and have your chance to win over $3,000 in FREE raffle prizes…FOR FREE!

Plus, each month you can support a great organization in your community by making a donation. Good karma for your awesome night of FREE fun! Get all the details on your city registration page.

Bring your friends, kids, parents, even friendly dogs- Adventure Run is FREE Fun for people of all ages and levels.

http://www.adventurerun.com/berkeley/
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the New Whole Foods off the Gillman Exit
results.name: Adventure Run!!!

results.description:
Join us for a "dinner and sunset show" in Tilden Park. Fingers crossed for a clear night.


Hike: a 4-mile loop with 1,000ft elevation gain. There is a nice picnic area at the top where we can have dinner/snacks/wine while enjoying 360 views of the Bay. We may get fog or we may get views, I never know what the Bay Area weather gods have in store for us. Here's hoping for a clear night.


Dress for cold weather. We should be back at the cars by 9:30pm, depends how long we take at dinner. If you hiked with me before, you know we tend to go slower than most meetups so we can enjoy the scenery and the conversation. Fast-pace hikers are welcome to join and run ahead - all I ask is that you please wait at all trail intersections esp. during night hikes!


Bring: water, dinner for yourself and snacks/sweets/wine to share if you want, warm layers, scarf, hat, gloves (it's usually windy and chilly at the dinner spot and we're not heading back early just because you didn't come prepared for the cold), and a headlamp/ flashlight/ flashlight app. We'll walk by Little Farm - bring some celery if you want to make friends with the residents.


Restrooms: There is a restroom at the trailhead.

Dogs: Sorry, no dogs allowed on this route :(


Kids: You can always bring kids on my hikes. I trust that you read the event description and can tell whether this would be a fun experience for them.

Attendance Note: If you sign up to attend, you will be counted on to show up. So please keep your RSVP up to date to reflect your intentions to join us. All members who do not show up will be recorded as a 'no show' in the system. Members with 3 or more No Shows will be removed from the group.

Waitlist: If you're on the waitlist, you will not be automatically moved into the "going" list if a spot opens up; you have to manually add yourself. So keep an eye out for the notifications/ emails from Meetup that a spot has opened up. Everyone will get a chance at the open spot, regardless of your position on the waitlist.


Questions? My number is posted above under the event location. Please call/text/pm or post a comment here should you have any questions about our hike.

DIRECTIONS AND PARKING

Click on the event location and a map to the meeting spot should open up. Whichever way you get into Tilden, follow signs for "Little Farm" and you'll find us. We will meet just before the gate for the Little Farm Parking Lot, where Central Park Dr meets Canon Dr. Please park alongside Central Park Drive, OUTSIDE the Little Farm parking lot. That lot closes at sunset and I don't want to risk anyone getting locked in.

<a href="http://goo.gl/maps/bxmvG"></a>

Please look up or ask me for directions AHEAD OF TIME. It sucks getting lost in Tilden with no cell reception (been there, done that). We will only wait a few minutes past the posted start time.
results.name: Dinner and sunset hike in Tilden Park

results.description:
Kim Thuy Seelinger, the Director of the Sexual Violence Program of the UC Human Rights Center, will highlight our Annual Meeting with a presentation on "Conflict Zones and Living Rooms: Common Challenges in the Fight Against Sexual Violence". Her Program recently received the prestigious 2015 MacArthur Foundation Award for Creative and Effective Institutions---a prize of $1 million dollars given to only nine non-profit organizations around the world.
Ms. Seelinger will tell us what her Program has accomplished in its first 20 years, what their plans are for creating an endowment and expanding their program, and how the League might be of assistance in advancing their goals. Her presentation will begin at 6:30.

Optional Buffet dinner at 5:30 ; speaker at 6:30; business meeting at 7:30
The buffet dinner will feature a delicious array of salads provided by Bette's Diner, along with baked dessert goods, coffee, and lemonade. The charge for dinner is $17, and diners can call the office [masked]), send email ([masked]) or pay by credit card via PayPal (www.lwvbae.org/annualmeeting) by Monday, May 25, the last day to make a reservation. You may also elect to bring your own food or come just for the presentation.
results.name: Challenges in the Fight Against Sexual Violence

group.name: League of Women Voters of Berkeley, Albany, Emeryville

results.description:
Join us for a mid week 5-10 miles in Redwood Regional Park at a moderate pace.

A route will be decided prior to departing, and we may split into groups if enough people show up to accommodate different paces and distances. The trails in Redwood are well marked, and there are usually options for extending or shortening runs.

Everyone is expected to be self-sufficient and prepared to return to the parking lot on his or her own if separated from the group. Please bring your own map if unfamiliar with the trails, hydration, fuel, electrolytes etc. There is water at the trail head, and sometimes printed maps available as well next to the bathrooms.

http://www.ebparks.org/parks/redwood#trailmap

Please bring a headlamp or flashlight for this run! It will be dark throughout most of the run until daylight savings time begins in the Spring.

Have fun!

<a href="http://www.ebparks.org/parks/redwood#trailmap"></a>
results.name: Thursday Evening Redwood Trail Run

venue.name: East Bay Healing Collective; Coming Home Room

results.description:
Hello Men,

Throughout history, men have gathered together around the campfire to set aside their daily rigors and commune with other men. It is a place where a man can put down his weapon, and simply enjoy the company of his friends, brothers, fathers and sons. Every man is equal around the campfire, and every man has the right to speak and be heard by his fellow tribesmen. We will partake in this time-honored tradition, and we will share our stories, our passions, and our vulnerability with each other—our spiritual kinsmen.


Women are biologically programmed to seek out the healthiest, highest status male. This is not even their choice: it is a biologic imperative, as with all animals, that allows them to find the fittest mate. In the modern dating world, the two crucial markers of “high status” for a man are his companions and his presence. Every high status man has healthy male bonds, male companions who trust him, who have his back, and who connect with him deeply. Every high status man also has presence.

Presence is about the deep coherence of your core-beliefs and your intentions and your words and your actions. The man who is ashamed of his own sexuality lacks presence. The man who is stuck in the whirl of his own anxious thoughts lacks presence. The man who fully occupies his entire body and is unapologetically grounded in who he is has presence. The man who can survey the possibilities around him while relaxing in a place of absolutely calm confidence has presence. Nature is the great teacher of presence. We will explore presence in depth through practices such as Shinrin-yoku, or Forest Bathing. We will learn to sense our cores, while holding awareness of the environment around us through meditation and mindfulness. By exploring bird language and our emotional ties to the ocean, we will understand how the connection to Nature promotes happiness and a sense of wonder. All of this deeply enhances presence.

This retreat is about male-bonding and presence. Through these practices we will learn how to be present, grounded and more connected to ourselves while connecting with others, instead of losing ourselves in an attempt to connect.


What you will get:

• Presence

• Connection with nature

• Reduction of stress and anxiety

• Spiritual inspiration

• Connection with other men

____________________________________________

This weekend course is part of the Unleashing Your Inner Badass Program. A program designed to help men step into their power as leaders both in life and with women.

The Badass program is for you if you are willing to:

• be coachable

• challenge yourself

• let go of being right

• be authentic

• be genuine

• be honest

• be vulnerable

We will only be accepting 10-12 men only as this is an intimate experience.

If you are interested in the course, please contact, Elizabeth Maria Cruz at [masked] or (415) 448-7218.

Sincerely,
The Badass Team,
Gregg, David, Mike and Elizabeth
results.name: MEN'S WRKSHP: Presence as a Way of Connecting with Women

results.description:
Here's one for you, East-Bay-ers!

Although I'm not very familiar with the East Bay, I know that's where many awesome people live -- people who can't always make it into the city for karaoke. So join me at Mel-O-Dees, my favorite karaoke place in the EB! It is laid back and usually we have the karaoke mic to ourselves! Also, it is very close to the El Cerrito BART station, which is an added bonus!

If you love singing, getting your drink on, or just enjoy watching others sing, please join me in El Cerrito! I look forward to seeing old friends and making new ones!

http://www.melodeelounge.com/el_cerrito_events.html
http://www.yelp.com/biz/mel-o-dee-el-cerrito


<Hosted with SFBA Karaoke group>

results.description:
I've been fascinated by night + low light photography ever since I saw photos by Berkeleyites Sherry Glassman and John Vias. Meet us at 4th Street at twilight to find out how you can do it.

https://nightphotographs.wordpress.com/

http://www.berkeleyside.com/2011/05/19/night-owl-captures-theatricality-of-berkeley-after-dark/

SLR + Tripod helpful (that's the best way to get sharp images), but not required - you'll probably get interesting photos with an iPhone or point-and-shoot camera. Ambient light is best, so it's important to know how to turn off the flash.

Celebrate freedom to take photos night & day - Meet at the Peet's Wall - 1776 Fourth St, Berkeley, CA 94710

Ira Serkes

Many of my low light and night photos are at my photo sites:

https://www.pinterest.com/serkes/

http://serkes.smugmug.com/

These are the wonderful folks who taught me everything I know about night photography.

http://www.apertureacademy.com/photography-workshops-san-francisco-night-shooting.php
results.name: 4th Street Berkeley Twilight & Night Photo Meetup

results.description:
Come join us for an open study session at the Berkeley Library, South Branch, in their Community Room. The library is close to Ashby BART station. Tables, chairs, projector, and Wi-Fi included.

This meetup will be a self-directed study session without a fixed plan or leader. Just bring whatever tutorials, books, courses, or projects that you're working on. You can meet people, find a partner for pair programming, talk about technology, or just work on a project or tutorial. All levels are welcome.

If people want to use the first hour for short presentations with the projector, we could do that. If you have an idea for a short presentation, send an email to Josh at codeselfstudy (dot com).


If you're looking for ideas about what to work on, check out some of the discussions we've had at the last meetings.

Chatroom: #codeselfstudy
Forum: CodeSelfStudy.com/forum
Wiki: CodeSelfStudy.com/w
Facebook: Facebook.com/codeselfstudy
Twitter: Twitter.com/codeselfstudy
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the meeting room. Call this number if you can't find it: 510-705-3422
results.name: Open Study Session (Berkeley Library, South Branch)

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
